source.raw_text:
The "Gladiator Squat" is a dynamic kettlebell movement combining a bottoms-up goblet squat with a pullover transition into a back squat, working legs (quads, glutes, hamstrings, adductors) heavily, plus core, shoulders, grip, and back for stability, improving mobility, power, and coordination through hip flexion/extension, knee flexion/extension, and trunk stabilization patterns. [1, 2, 3]  
Muscles Worked 

• Primary Movers: Quadriceps, Glutes (maximus), Hamstrings, Adductors (inner thighs). 
• Stabilizers & Support: Core (abdominals, spinal erectors), Shoulders (grip, control), Back. [1, 3, 4]  

Movement Pattern 
This complex, compound movement involves several phases: 

1. Bottoms-Up Goblet Squat: Kettlebell held upside-down (by horns) to deep squat, engaging legs and core. 
2. Pullover Transition: Standing up, pull the kettlebell overhead and onto the upper back. 
3. Back Squat: Perform a standard back squat with the kettlebell in place. 
4. Explosive Return: Drive up and smoothly return the kettlebell to the starting goblet position. [3]  

Key Joint Actions 

• Eccentric Phase (Lowering): Hip flexion, knee flexion, ankle dorsiflexion (bringing foot towards shin). 
• Concentric Phase (Lifting): Hip extension, knee extension, ankle plantarflexion (pointing toes). [2]  

Benefits 

• Full-Body Strength & Power: Integrates lower body, core, and upper body. 
• Mobility & Stability: Enhances thoracic (upper back) mobility and shoulder stability. 
• Coordination: Builds functional strength through dynamic transitions. [3]  

**Citations:**

[1] https://gym-mikolo.com/blogs/home-gym/uncover-the-science-the-complete-breakdown-of-squat-muscles
[2] https://blog.nasm.org/biomechanics-of-the-squat
[3] https://www.facebook.com/kettlebellkings/videos/gladiator-squat/1168831658370502/
[4] https://barbell-logic.com/muscles-worked-in-the-squat/
